comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
@deathlord87 It's a bit confusing, but this is not a global error/result listener. Instead it's linked to the given target. So for a given image view, as long as the arguments to glide do not change, the handler passed in will handle exceptions/completions for any loads into that image view.
Each request handler therefore may handle multiple loads, but there can be up to one handler per view/target.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I think Runtime.getRuntime.freememory isn't really accurate. It looks like it gives you the amount of free memory out of the memory that is currently allocated, not out of the maximum that can be allocated. If you have 22mb allocated, and are using 21mb, freememroy would give you 1mb even if the maximum amount of memory you can use is 60mb.
I found this helpful: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3571203/what-is-the-exact-meaning-of-runtime-getruntime-totalmemory-and-freememory
Or were you thinking of something else?

I am not entirely sure how to check for TIFFs in the general case to be honest. What I have done now is, instead of looking for GIFs in order to skip the pool, I skip it if the type is not JPG, PNG or PNG_A (which I changed from the previous APNG which means something else btw).
This way when new types of images are added, the pool skipping will happen automatically unless we add that type to the set of recognized types. Also, I am hoping since I haven't tested, a TIFF will not return JPG or PNG with the current code, so the skipping will happen.
Let me know if this is sufficient.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
My only hesitation with this is that it implies that the current target interface isn't sufficient. If it's possible to fix or expand that interface so that you can do what you need to do without having direct access to the ImageView that would probably be nicer.
As an alternative you could also subclass ImageViewTarget and override onImageReady in the subclass. You'd then call Glide.load(yourModel).into(new ImageViewTargetSubclass(yourImageView)).
It would be nice to not have to cast your target to a specific subclass in the listener to get the functionality you need. I'm not particularly happy with the target interface and I haven't used it a ton, so if you have any ideas on how it might be improved I'd love to hear them.

comments.author: savvasdalkitsis
comments.text:
Sounds good. The only subtle point is that we need the listeners to be called even if the initial call failed to load. Basically, any time I call Glide.into, I should receive a callback no matter what.
To keep the API cleaner, it might be good to specify a third callback like onImageAlreadyLoaded or something but still call the error callback if it fails to load again (either from any cache or the network).

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Yes I meant Glide#cancel, not clear. I was also incorrect in my previous post about the custom subclass.
You can and probably should be using a subclass of ImageViewTarget. However I was incorrect to say that you could pass in a new instance of your target subclass for each call to load. Instead you need to create and retain a single target per image view. If you pass in an ImageView directly, Glide will do this for you by calling ImageView#setTag. Otherwise it's up to you to retain the target in a non-static way.
The simplest thing to do is also to call setTarget if you're loading into a view, or if you're using the viewholder pattern, to add your target to your viewholder. You could also subclass the view directly and implement the interface in that subclass, although I think that's a bit uglier.
The fundamental problem is that we need to be able to retrieve information about the previous load when a new load starts so that we can do things like reuse bitmaps.
Sorry for the confusion!

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
For closure I've thought about this a lot and ultimately I'm wary of putting this kind of logic in Target. Target ideally is a dumb receptacle for data. However to address this class of issues, I've updated the animation logic to be more robust and I've also expanded the RequestListener interface so that it is always called whenever the request interacts with the target and so that it has the ability to override the default behavior as you're doing here.
Hopefully that's something of a compromise, you can see these changes in the 3.0a branch.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Sorry for the delay in reviewing this and thanks for putting up the code, I really appreciate the contribution. One general comment: It looks like this doesn't make any attempt to scale the image down to near the target width and height before performing the crop?
If so thats a break with the centerCrop method (https://github.com/bumptech/glide/blob/master/library/src/com/bumptech/glide/resize/load/ImageResizer.java#L199). It may imply that we should have a separate transformation that does the scaling, but for now it would probably be best to add that same scaling functionality here or at least document that this method doesn't scale first.
Without the scale you could end up cropping a large portion of your image out, which probably isn't quite what you want.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Yes, but you can make the history slightly cleaner by rebasing on top of the most recent changes. It's a  git thing.
If you branch at commit A, and create commit B on your branch, but in the meantime, commits C and D are added on top of A in master:
A B
C
D
You get a branch in the commit history when you merge:
master
A
B
merge B (see e3524cc)
C
D
If you instead rebase and then merge, you get a 'fast forward' and have a linear history:
master
A
C
D
B
No big deal either way, some people think all 'merges' in git should be fast forwards and therefore all branches should be rebased before the merge. Doesn't matter much to me either way, if you don't care, I'm happy to just merge.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Hmm, that's new, - and finally I know what it means if a commit has 2 parents :) - but I think that's the way it should be... if you draw your commit history a little differently:
master
  A
 / \
|   |
C   B (on branch)
D   |  |
|  /   ˇ
Merge B
|
...

This way it's clear what was the order of the commits in reality.
This is what I'm missing in SVN, when you merge you just get merge B out of thin air, it looks like GIT at least shows what was merged separately and altogether which is an advantage.
<rant>
As I see this is a way to push the merging and testing the latest to the owner of the branch/PR instead of the master owner dealing with it. Also "some people think all 'merges' in git should be fast forwards"  sounds like some strong voiced urban legend started a tendency, and now people just follow it without questioning it - this may be the definition of de-facto standard and/or "historical reasons". But as you know I'm not a GIT expert, my first commit was a few days ago :)
</rant>
I would keep the "Merge" commits as well if I had a repo, but here yo' da boss. I'll rebase it now.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: If I see it correctly from the diff, you've created an optional Key argument for the load overloads. Why didn't you go with the usual builder pattern like .cacheSignature(Key)?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Amusingly I didn't even think of adding it to the Builder pattern until you mentioned it. In part because I think it's so closely tied to the model you pass in. You could make an argument that the builder arguments apply generally to a style of load for any model, but the signature typically would apply only to a specific model (url etc).
I'm not sure that's a good enough reason to special case it though?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Try to look from the user point of view... and use it in a sentence:
Glide.with(this).using(...).load(uri, key).into(view);
versus
Glide.with(this).using(...).cacheSignature (key).load(uri).into(view);
For one: you're not loading the key into the view, that's only for cache refresh.
Second I personally like to not repeat code and the way I used Picasso and then Glide was to create my own factories pre-attaching the error Drawable, transformation and other stuff and returning a builder to call .load.into on it or override whatever special thing I wanted (e.g. noTransform). As far as I remember this pattern is already a little bit broken because a lot of stuff can only be specified after the .load with Glide, however my intuition would put the most varying parts last. If I were to use this key overload I would probably set it in the factory, calculating/caching the versionCode or hashOfApk there.
It feels like using it in an Adapter for example would pull the versionCode/hash calculation there which really should have to do anything in an adapter.
Third, when you say it's tied to the model it feels like you're only thinking about the opposite of using versionCode and having a separate Key for everything.
Please note that I like to trigger thoughts in other people and defend my initial view, though usually it's really easy to find arguments for both sides. You most likely see now where my original question came from and have enough to make an informed decision.

comments.author: pavlospt

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
This looks great! Thanks for putting this up.
There's one more problem we need to solve here: cancellation/resource recycling. Currently you're just relying on the base implementation of getRequest() and setRequest() which sets the current Request as an instance variable of the RemoteViewsTarget. The Request object is used by Glide to cancel requests and ensure ordering if you start multiple requests for the same Target.
By doing so, you're requiring that users pass in the same RemoteViewsTarget instance every time they want to load an image into the RemoteViewsTarget. If they create a new Target each time, they may see issues where images from loads started earlier replace those from loads started later.
To fix this we have two options that I can think of:

Document thoroughly that users must pass in the same instance of RemoteViewsTarget for each load.
Use a static WeakHashMap of RemoteViews -> WeakReference<Request> in getRequest() and setRequest(). As long as someone is holding on to the remote views, the key will be strongly referenced and as long as a request is in progress, Glide will keep a strong reference to the Request, so for the life of a single Request, the entry should remain. Once the Request completes, there may no longer be strong references, but that's ok because we don't need to cancel in progress loads.

We solve this problem for Views by using setTag() and getTag(), which aren't available for RemoteViews. Although it's more complicated and static maps are hacky, I'm inclined to say 2 is the better choice here because it allows for the most intuitive API.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I found a checkstyle plugin for intellij that should work with AndroidStudio.

Preferences -> Plugins -> Browse Repositories -> install Checkstyle - IDEA and restart
Preferences -> Other Settings -> CheckStyle -> Add Glide's checkstyle.xml file as a config file using Glide's root directory as the path for the property,
Right click on library -> Analyze -> Run inspection by name ->  CheckStyle.

That will show you a list of the checkstyle failures. They will also show up as errors in the file as you're editing, however they don't appear to block the build from completing (I'm still trying to figure out if this is possible).

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: You can also run ./gradlew checkstyle and take a look at the failures in the build/reports directory (it will give you a complete path after the failure)

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Concern: metadata without a value looks strange.
Wouldn't it be better if you did name="com.bumptech.glide.module.flickr" value="full.class.name", less parsing (no need for substring, but you can keep the startswith check) and better readability, compliance.
The doc for metadata.name says to prefix your name with package: http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/meta-data-element.html

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
@TWiStErRob The reason why the fully qualified class name has to be in the key is that there can be only one metadata tag for a given key. If we use anything other than the fully qualified class name, it's possible a user would accidentally try to add two different implementations with the same key (two different classes in the same package for example). If they did so, we'd have no way to detect the error because the manifest merger/parser would silently merge the two.
I agree the syntax is funky, but unless there's some way around the fully qualified class name issue, I'm not sure we have anything useful to put in the value.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Note that I still left flicker in the name, which is just a random name. That name after that is not used anywhere just helps readability, users can organize modules nicer. E.g. for okhttp it would be different, the point is to start it with ...glidemodule..
I read the design doc lately and as I remember the merger will conflict if two modules have the same name after glidemodule, but the values are different.
The best would be a multivalued metadata which is not supported sadly.

comments.author: coveralls
comments.text: Coverage decreased (-0.03%) to 86.28% when pulling d6eb14d on sjudd:master into e099ef6 on bumptech:master.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Also in case of placeholders (e.g. I hate duplicating the package name so I have a placeholder for it like ${packageName}.subpackage.Class) it's cleaner to start with that instead of having it in the middle. Placeholders are required because the .sub.Class format support is limited to a few elements.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
We've actually tried something like this with user specifiable names, and found that people would still occasionally choose the same name. Using the class name just completely eliminates the possibility, unless they add the same class twice, in which case ignoring the second copy should be fine.
We could drop glidemodule: altogether, but then we wouldn't be able to assert as much (malformed class name and failing to implement GlideModule would have to be ok).
We could append :glidemodule instead if you think that's cleaner?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Another option would be to leave the fully qualified class name as the key, but set glidemodule as the value. Maybe that's cleaner? It would at least avoid the string parsing.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Hmm that's interesting... just realized: all of these are hacks, so I guess the last one is the best of them you're taking onto consideration.
Rant follows :) Your response to people occasionally choosing the same names is the approach I saw at my university in the classes following my year, a lot of students were failing the most basic programming tests so they made them easier every semester. My view/approach is always: use stuff as designed, so keys as keys and value as values. End of rant.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I hear you. It's worth keeping in mind though that it's not even necessarily possible for people to do the right thing. If you have a number of independent library projects, each owned by separate teams, and multiple of those teams define their own modules, we don't want to force people to go inspect all of the other team's modules before they come up with a module name (or keep a list of all used names somewhere...).
I agree it's the best of bad options, I'll move module into the value and remove the prefix.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Hmm, isn't this just hiding another bug? (covering the symptom)
I thought draw is called on the UI thread, and so does recycle so they should be ordered and the target be cleared as soon as (or even before) recycle happens, i.e. draw cannot be called with an invalid bitmap.
What makes this invariant not true?

comments.author: SeongUgJung
comments.text:
maybe it's hiding another bug.
but sometimes glide' LruBitmapPool or System' GC remove drawing bitmap.
especially low memory device was occurred frequency.
my crash was occured almost by Glide' Cannot draw recycled bitmaps.
GifDrawable is checked recycled or not.
but GlideBitmapDrawable isn't checked.
I thought it's more critical than hiding bug.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Yes this is hiding another bug. We should not be recycling resources that are still in use. The lifecycle is roughly:

Decode bitmap in background
Pass Bitmap to Target on main thread and draw it.
Clear Target (or view) by either calling Glide.clear() or starting a new load into the same Target (or view).
Return Bitmap to pool (and go back to #1).

If you are starting multiple loads into the same view or otherwise retaining a Bitmap after starting a new load or clearing an old load, you will see this exception. If you want to load multiple images, you need to make sure they're either loaded into separate Targets (or views), or that you avoiding using any loaded resources after a new load is started or the Target is cleared.
Probably worth filing a new issue with whatever issue you're seeing so we can look in to it.

@sjudd
ah~ I understand. I guess multiple loading point in my app.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
@TWiStErRob Git blame says: #202. GifDrawable switches back and forth between two targets on each frame but doesn't really handle when a single frame fails to load.
A better fix would be to re-use the same Target twice in a row if a single frame fails to load, so the GIF would drop a frame rather than briefly stop drawing at all.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
This doesn't look right to me. It seems to have too many assumptions about the layout hierarchy above the image view.
Consider for example a LinearLayout with an ImageView with match/match and a weight, one of those match parents will be wrongly "measured" by Glide. Those width/height are just hints to the ViewGroups.
Another case I can see failing is RelativeLayout where the contained ImageView has match parent but other constraints make it way smaller (toLeftOf).
I think this is why the current implementation is saying "it's pending" and lets the Android View hierarchy do the measure/layout cycle correctly.

comments.author: nemphys
comments.text: Sounds fair, but I think that I went through the trouble to do this because the default implementation did not work properly (at least in my use case; please note that, as I said, I did this a while ago and can't remember exactly what was wrong). Will have to take a look at the code again and report back.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: The behaviour you're referring to may have changed in Glide v3.5.0, see #274 and related commits.

comments.author: nemphys
comments.text:
OK, just took a look at the (unmodified) ViewTarget class and it seems that since getSizeForParam returns "param" when layoutParams is present and not wrap_content, isSizeValid returns false in checkCurrentDimens, which in turn just returns (no callbacks). Therefore, the view is not measured when match_parent is set.
Please correct me if I'm wrong.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: checkCurrentDimens should only be called when getWidth already returns the laid out size. Note that the entry point is getSize(cb), which also calls isSizeValid, which fails the first time for match_parent (not a valid size) and then registers the ViewTreeObserver. Which when called by Android calls checkCurrentDimens.

comments.author: nemphys
comments.text:
OK, you're right, but the images are still never loaded when I set my view to match_parent... Any ideas why?
Will try to debug this and see I find anything interesting.

comments.author: nemphys
comments.text:
I started debugging, but it gets a little complicated, since I am using a custom view inside a view pager and that's where the problem appears. Too late for today, will investigate further tomorrow.
Anyway, I am closing this PR, since it seems that the stock code works OK in simple use cases with match_parent enabled.
Thank you for your time.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Feel free to open an issue with a minimal example project, with more context, like exact view hierarchy it's easier to see the problem. Also try just setting the image without Glide as control experiment?

comments.author: nemphys
comments.text:
After digging a little further, I found the culprit: the ImageView I am using in this specific scenario is actually an ImageView subclass that supports zooming/panning etc. and it handles its onMeasure event in a way that was conflicting with the callback; changed some bits and all is OK now.
The problem is that the callback method, although ingenious, causes trouble in other scenarios, too:
I am implementing shared element transitions between fragments (with match_parent ImageViews) and, in this case, the view measurements for the shared element animations are captured only once and pretty early, which means that the callback has not been called yet, leading to wrong measurements and weird animations.
All I can think of in order to overcome this is to make a custom Target subclass that will use this PR's logic to calculate dimensions (since the ImageView is the only child in my case, so it does not face the issue you mentioned).
Any other ideas would be appreciated...

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Oh, I forgot that it's the resource that he says leaks, but still, why keep the Request in memory?
By the way, @zhywang, if you're in a ListView then the next request into the recycled list item's image will overwrite the existing Target in the tag, and also the drawable will be cleared by the next request.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
No good reason to keep the Request in memory, it's just a memory leak waiting to happen. I'm happy with the pull request.
However, I do want to double check and make sure this isn't leaking resources in a way I'm not currently seeing. There may be another bug, or something else we can/should do.

comments.author: zhywang
comments.text: @sjudd Yes I did see the references to GlideBitmapDrawableResource from the ImageView.tag in the heap dump of our app. After more spike, I found this patch is not good enough, the root cause is that after the request is finished, it still keeps the GlideBitmapDrawableResource reference, so to avoid memory leak, maybe we should do a Glide.cancel() on the image view after  the request is finished, in the client (our app) side.

comments.author: zhywang
comments.text: @TWiStErRob Yes you are correct, in a ListView the next request into the item will overwrite the Target and clear the drawable, however, if I have many types in the ListView(http://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/BaseAdapter.html#getItemViewType%28int%29), maybe some items won't be overwrite (that's what our app does), then the  drawables is in memory, causes the memory leak. I think for this case, maybe it's better to handle it in our app.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: @zhywang Yeah you if you have a lot of different view types you may want to consider adding a ListView RecyclerListener or a RecyclerView RecyclerListener and calling clear. Both the Request and the View will reference whatever resource you've loaded. clear() should remove both references.

comments.author: zhywang
comments.text:
@sjudd RecyclerListener is cool. In our app the image is in a complex layout, I resolve this problem by add a OnAttachStateChangeListener to it, to avoid impact our architecture too much.
I think this pull request can be closed now, maybe in the future glide could use the OnAttachStateChangeListener to clear the request (that's how Google Volley NetworkImageView does) :)

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Thanks for the PR!
Some (late) feedback: In general I prefer putting the if outside the try, because entering/exiting try may be slower.
Even though I didn't find any hard evidence on this in the last 10 minutes of research, this statement is convinced me to continue preferring it:

Placing code inside a try-catch block inhibits certain optimizations that modern JVM implementations might otherwise perform.

It also helps devs to skip the try block if they're reading code and they know a certain variable's nullity.

comments.author: sjudd

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Nice :)
I have one concern: DefaultDiskCacheFactory gets the path in the constructor, but what if I need to do I/O (e.g. File.exists()) to determine the folder I want to use. build() is called in the background and could call a getDiskCacheFolder() method and the child classes can then override that.
At the same time if you leave the diskCacheFolder field a default implementation of getDiskCacheFolder() can use that field for simple cases.
This way it's possible to use DefaultDCF with a folder in constructor, you can extend the class and override a method. You may also let InternalDCF/ExternalDCF's static methods override that one and they become extensible too.

comments.author: TWiStErRob

Hmm, actually getExternalCacheDir() already does I/O to determine the result:
android.app.ContextImpl#ensureDirsExistOrFilter

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
I'm confused. In 3.6.0 there is a: gifDrawable.getDecoder().getCurrentFrameIndex(). It looks like the 4.0 refactor got rid of that, but still the current frame is available through:
state.frameLoader.gifDecoder.getCurrentFrameIndex() which I think is preferable to having a copy of the frame index, say, to maintain compatibility.
As an alternative I think state.frameLoader.current.index (with a new getter on frameLoader) could be used to be in sync with how draw uses state.frameLoader.current (getCurrentFrame()).

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
@TWiStErRob maintaining a copy here is ok I think. Otherwise you'd always return the index of the frame you're loading, rather than the one you're displaying. It's also always possible that an intermediate frame will fail to load, so you you can't even guarantee that the frame you're loading is just the next frame after the one you're displaying.
Still looking in to the travis build...

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Take a look at the alternative I proposed too, because that's totally different. That would be the only way to get the same index as draw gets or the bitmap should be retrieved at the same time the index is cached.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Ah I see what you're saying. That would make a bit more sense with the current structure, really the Drawable doesn't need to know anything about the current index. We should also probably be keeping track of loops some other way, rather than passing the index into the callback.

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback!  I'm happy to fix the implementation. As of now, GifFrameLoader.gifDecoder is private with no accessor, so something will have to change.  I'll go with @TWiStErRob 's "alternative" approach of exposing the index off of DelayTarget.  I'm not going to mess with loopCount as that seems a bit more involved.

comments.text: One question - With this change, it's pretty easy to refactor out the frameIndex parameter from the onFrameReady callback interface, since that method can just call getFrameIndex().  Whats nice is that makes it consistent where the code gets the index from.  The biggest impact is the tests, which require a few extra mockito calls.  Thoughts?

comments.author: joshzana
comments.text: One interesting thing I noticed during testing - the first time after starting the animation in GifDrawable#onFrameReady, the index is 1.  This is because both ByteBufferGifDecoder#decode and GifFrameLoader#loadNextFrame call advance before onFrameReady.  After looping it does properly start at 0.  I am not sure if this is by design or not, but I'm happy to open a separate issue if needed.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
I have one bigger  concern (other than my small line comments):
Applying .centerInside() to a load may produce an unnecessarily large Bitmap. Imagine one's loading a 16x16px icon into a 512x512px space. This means that Glide's centerInside will create a 512px Bitmap, but there will be 240px padding inside where there's nothing. This is a waste of memory considering the ImageView would handle this for us if it's ScaleType is set to centerInside. So I'm inclined to say that the automatic transformation for ImageViews should be a little different: return the original Bitmap if it's smaller than the requested size, and fitCenter if it's bigger. But, the padded version is still viable in situations like toBytes() or asBitmap() with custom targets because there it is better to have a Bitmap that has the requested size than implementing centerInside somehow every single time. The best solution would be to parameterize all centerInside calls with a boolean padSmaller argument, so the user can/has to decide which logic to use.

comments.author: josemontiel
comments.text: Thanks for the feedback @TWiStErRob. Right on it!

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I think you can disregard padding entirely, it's hard for me to imagine a scenario where you want extra transparency baked into the Bitmap.
I'd just check if the width and height are greater than the target, and if so, fitCenter, and otherwise just return the original Bitmap.
Transformations never promise that the Bitmap they return will exactly match the requested width and height.
Thanks for putting this up!

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
@sjudd what if the requested transformation doesn't match scaleType?
ImageView.scaleType = fitCenter
.centerInside() on load
I would still expect a small image to be centered in a middle of a bigger space.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Oh I wouldn't, I'd expect the Bitmap to remain at the smallest possible size (to minimize memory usage), but for the Bitmap to be stretched by the view when it's drawn to match the requested scale type.
None of our other transformations try to override a conflicting scale type set on a view, I don't think we need to do so here either.

comments.author: TWiStErRob

comments.text:
I think the :library module is not a release artifact. What you download when you referece Glide in your build.gradle is the glide module's output, which is a .jar. This is why I said the following in #646:

I guess an AAR distribution could be made to include this, since it will help some people (using @aar), but it won't make AAR the required form of consuming Glide.

There's probably some Gradle magic needed to produce both .jar and .aar from module :glide or a separate module for AAR build. Also see scripts/upload.gradle.

comments.author: vanniktech
TWiStErRob
comments.text: This is a library and not everyone uses Gradle. Since Glide has no resources it doesn't make sense to force AAR. Also for this little change (copying 2 lines into a proguard file) it's not worth to break compatibility with those users. Eclipse for example is horrible for consuming AARs (especially with Maven) last time I checked... that was when I started using IDEA as main IDE. For non-Gradle it's easier to just drop the glide jar into the libs folder and it just works, with aar you have to extract and import a separate project, set up dependencies... This is why I'm suggesting (see above in other comments) a double-distribution of aar/jar side by side. @sjudd's intentions may have been different originally, the above is just my view.

comments.text: I'd be up for distributing both aar & jar.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Although things have vastly improved over the last couple of years for AARs, I still agree that having a fat jar available is helpful for some users.
I'm totally ok with AAR+Jar.
I think if we do release an AAR, we can upload gradle projects individually (ie library + third_party/disklrucache + ...) rather than trying to combine them into a single AAR before upload. It would be a little weird to have AAR users depend on glide:library and jar users depend on the existing glide:glide, but it's probably worth the simplification in our build rules.

comments.author: vanniktech
comments.text: So basically we'll have the old way plus for each subproject it's on AAR package and then you will just include whatever you need?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: I think glide:glide should be released as both AAR and JAR, there's no point in releasing each submodule because they're private to glide. There are many artifacts (e.g. intg libs) already in the maven repos, I don't think we need more. They are also not really useful by themselves, or already have official releases by other names.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
@TWiStErRob I see what you're saying, but since maven and gradle handle transitive dependencies, there's no reason not to take advantage of that and upload each subproject individually. It's fairly painful to combine subprojects into fat jars/aars. At the same time, subprojects encourage code re-use, and allow greater parallelism, which decreases build times.
I think the extra few largely useless artifacts is worth the simplification to our build process. Particularly since we can still easily point people to the single artifact they actually want. This strategy also seems to match the direction other libraries are moving in, where the library is broken down into multiple components.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: This all assumes that you use Maven or Gradle. The point of having a fat jar is? to help people without those awesome systems. If we drop that support (of copying a single Glide jar to /libs) we might as well just change =jar to =aar in the properties file (they can extract classes.jar from aar too). Am I missing something?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Oh sorry I was misleading. I totally agree we should continue to release a single JAR as well as the AARs. I just don't think we need to create a single fat AAR, but can instead release multiple smaller AARs that match the internal project structure.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Ah, ok. Good then. We don't have to have all smaller libs as AARs, e.g. gifdecoder wouldn't gain much from being an AAR.
A note on build times: doing that you said will really help us, but also think about consumers. Consuming an AAR is not cheap. You know that the Android Gradle plugin extracts the contents every time (clean) just to be able to reference the jar inside (and merge resources). Compare this to adding a path to classpath, the path of the downloaded/cached jar file in the .m2|gradle cache directory. So releasing aar pushes some build time from the libs to all of the consumers...
A side note: While I'm arguing for people who don't use Gradle/Maven I think anyone who is developing Android apps and not using AS(IDEA)/Gradle are shooting themselves in the foot, but we should let them suffer if that's the path they choose :) or forced to choose :(

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Ah right, thanks for reminding me about gifencoder. The file is in a separate folder to meet Google's standards for open source code (all third party code goes into a top-level folder called third_party). That said, it really ought to be a separate library project, just like the other two third_party projects. It's fine to leave as is for now, that's my mess I can clean up later.
As for versioning, there isn't really any reason why those integration libraries shouldn't just match Glide's. I can imagine a scenario in which someone put up a PR for one of the libraries and I might want to release just the library without releasing Glide and would be unable to do so because of the current versioning scheme, but that hasn't happened yet. I agree the right solution is to either switch them all to match Glide's or keep them all independent. You don't need to do that here either.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: I think that's not correct, you should also clear it when there was no error: "done with it", so that catch should be finally.

comments.author: aam
comments.text: @TWiStErRob , thanks for taking a look, but that is exactly it: you should not need to call cancel() if get() completed successfully. That matches semantics outlined here: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Future.html. Why do you think you should?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: It's confusing because that object is both a Future and a Target. As you say it's not good to cancel successful futures, but it's suggested to clear Targets that are not needed any more. Clear would free up any resources, but I guess it doesn't really apply to loads that end in a File, because they're not resource intensive. @sjudd?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Looks like the build is failing due to the comment: :third_party:gif_decoder:mockableAndroidJar/home/travis/build/bumptech/glide/library/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/request/transition/ViewPropertyTransition.java:12: warning - Tag @link: reference not found: android.animation.ObjectAnimator /home/travis/build/bumptech/glide/library/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/request/RequestFutureTarget.java:50: warning - End Delimiter } missing for possible See Tag in comment string: "A {@link java.util.concurrent.Future} implementation for Glide that can be used to load resources in a blocking manner on background threads.

Note - Unlike most targets, RequestFutureTargets can be used once and only once. Attempting A little odd that it's causing the failure but might make sense. @TWiStErRob @aam I took another look at this. Clear and cancel are equivalent, except that cancel unblocks the future's get method. Both methods will cause the request to be cancelled and resources to be released. From that perspective, it's probably best if we do in fact call clear() in a finally block (clear() is also thread safe).

comments.author: aam
comments.text: which clear()? requestManager.clear(target); or target.getRequest().clear()?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: requestManager.clear(target);

comments.author: TWiStErRob
aam
comments.text:
thanks Rob. But what about calling Future.cancel() on the FutureTarget?
Perhaps if we use .get(TIMEOUT), it becomes evident that in the exception handler besides clearing Target, the Future needs to be cancelled too.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Why would you need to cancel it? Your code is already past get(), which it must be because you're in finally, throwing or not. This means that it was either already cancelled or it returned a value and processing the returned File is completed or failed with an Exception.

comments.author: aam
comments.text: When Future get() throws an exception, the Future itself still might be running. In case of get(timeout) and TimeoutException it is particularly clear: take a look at here: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/Future.html

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
If get() throws CancellationException or ExecutionException then the job definitely failed. If get() returns a value it must have finished. If get(timeout) or get() throws InterruptedException, or if get(timeout) throws TimeoutException the job might still be running, you're right. So it's likely the best to keep the original target.cancel() wrapped in a null-check, and with parameter true (that param is not used, but in case it will be in the future I think true is better there, because the user really wants to cancel it). Glide also adheres to this sentence from the docs:

Once a computation has completed, the computation cannot be cancelled.

This means it's safe to cancel in finally: the state of isCancelled() and isDone() won't be modified if get() completed without exception.
What do you think?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: @sjudd where is the FutureTarget cancelled when requestManager.clear(target)? There's no code in onLoadCleared.

comments.author: aam
comments.text:
Yes, right.
It should be safe to call target.cancel(true) in finally, but it seems confusing, as you only need to cancel if one of those exceptions was thrown, right? I would keep it in catch clause in the javadoc section for clarity. Of course user is free to move the cancel around if they wish.

comments.author: aam
comments.text: Or is your point that you don't want to call cancel() (in the catch clause) followed up by call to clear() (in finally clause) as second is effectively redundant in case of exception?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
aam
comments.text:
Okay, that is fine, I put cancel() into finally clause.
The build still fails unfortunately, it seems to just hang for some reason.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Likely the parallel Gradle build. The newer plugins use much more resources with greater parallelism in-task (most notably dex), so parallelizing in-process (on Gradle level) really takes a toll on the host system (sometimes I can't even click with 8 cores and 16GB). I'm not sure if v1.2.3 is new enough to already do this though.

comments.author: dmapr
comments.text: It is not going to solve OOMs, but it will ensure that you will get a callback (onException) in your listener when an OOM occurs. Right now if an OOM occurs then you don't get any callback (neither onException nor onResourceReady). In our particular case it happens when loading large animated GIFs and it allows us to fallback to single frame loading.

comments.author: TWiStErRob

I guess it's reasonable to at least expose the error so you can respond to it.
Thanks for putting this up!

comments.text: @ihenchi I was wondering why you ignored my 3rd point in #1057 (comment), but then I investigated and I saw that it's not really possible, because that would crash the host application, because the exception is moved from the fetcher thread to the UI thread by the time we ask the listener if it's handled. @sjudd Do you think it is safe to ignore that point?

comments.author: dmapr
comments.text: Yes, sorry, forgot to reply to the third point. Yes, I don't think we can guarantee that the unprocessed exception can be delivered to the UncaughtThrowableStrategy once the EngineRunnable completes.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: There would be way, but it's hacky: somehow manually post a new Runnable to the thread pool which just re-throws the error.

comments.author: dmapr
comments.text: I believe such an approach would increase the complexity beyond our comfort level. Let's wait to see what @sjudd says before we start down that path.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Agreed, I'm not comfortable with it either, just an option.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
sjudd
comments.text: UncaughtThrowableStrategy isn't really an API, it's a way to expose errors that occur, primarily for developers. I think what we're saying with this PR is that an OOM shouldn't really be an error because there are times where OOMs are unavoidable.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Ah, true that.

would force users to attach listeners to each load to even see OOMs in logs.

Actually, this is currently true for all exceptions, if you want the stack trace. Since the exceptions are logged in log.tag.EngineRunnable anyway, the OOMs would be logged too.
So the change that will occur when merging this is that instead of perpetual placeholder OOMs would be showing the error drawable like any other exception, and the lifecycle methods will be called as expected. Degrading OOM from unexpected error to expected error.
@ihenchi @dmapr I think we're all on the same page. Please do the actions in #1057 (comment) and we're good to go.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Thanks for putting this up. I'm inclined to accept this I think. Can you briefly describe the new behavior for this images? I'd imagine it will match Chrome by running through all valid frames once and then failing when it reaches an invalid frame?
The only issue I could see is that it doesn't allow the app developer to easily tell that the GIF load won't behave as they expect. We don't have a way of communicating a partial failure at the moment.

comments.author: s1rius
comments.text:
Sorry for the delay.
With this PR, Glide will treat a damaged GIF as a normal GIF which contains some valid frames. The invalid frames will be ignored. And the valid frames will default keep looping not just run once.
If an user see a damaged GIF on web or gallery. I think, make the user see a valid GIF on an app which used Glide is better than display a placeholder image.
@sjudd

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
@sjudd when looking at the code this is what I concluded too. I guess there's no point it crashing the app when a bad image is loaded, but probably a warning log would be useful to communicate partial failure when header.getStatus() != GifDecoder.STATUS_OK.
@s1rius did you actually look into what's wrong with these files? Are there bytes missing from the end (partial file), or is it an encoder error, or maybe something else?

comments.author: s1rius
comments.text: @TWiStErRob I actually look into the wrong with this file, and I compared the bad file and the good file.The bad file lost many bytes.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
The only issue I could see is that it doesn't allow the app developer to easily tell that the GIF load won't behave as they expect. We don't have a way of communicating a partial failure at the moment.

@sjudd how about putting this logic behind an Option? The default would be as before in v3, but users who expect partial files (like @s1rius) can enable the option? Or the reverse: default is to decode and show everything, but strict users can disable partial decoding.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Option is ok with me for now, good idea.
Ideally you'd want some partial success indicator, but I can't think of way to do that without expanding a bunch of interfaces or changing the behavior of Targets.

comments.author: s1rius
comments.text:
Maybe decode and show everything is OK.
If I am an strict developer, I will guarantee every GIF upload to server is good. So my App displays every GIF correctly from server.
And I want to ignore bad GIFs stored in local. But I don't know which GIF is bad before decoding it. Instead, I display a placeholder image on the bad Gif position in my gallery Activity. It is not make sense.
So, I think decode and show everything is a good idea.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Tip: You don't need to restart, the same way you amended and force pushed the param name change you could've modified the branch either:

simply rolled the branch back one commit and force pushed to remove the irrelevant commit
commit an inverse of the irrelevant commit and squash all 3 (fix, irrelevant, -irrelevant) into a single commit on that branch and force push

Changing feature branches this way is safe because no-one should be working off your fork's branch.
Anyway, thanks for contributing, this should be merged soon.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
@sjudd this has a side effect:
compile 'com.github.bumptech.glide:volley-integration:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT'

Error: Module 'com.github.bumptech.glide:volley-integration:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT' depends on one or more Android Libraries but is a jar

+--- com.github.bumptech.glide:volley-integration:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT
     +--- com.android.volley:volley:1.0.0
     \--- com.github.bumptech.glide:glide:4.0.0-SNAPSHOT (*)

The old dep was distributed as both AAR and JAR: http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/mcxiaoke/volley/library/1.0.19/
The new dep is just AAR:
https://bintray.com/android/android-utils/com.android.volley.volley/view#files/com/android/volley/volley/1.0.0
As a workaround users can apply this:
compile('com.github.bumptech.glide:volley-integration:2.0.0-SNAPSHOT') {
    // exclude to prevent "depends on one or more Android Libraries but is a jar", but still depend on it below
    exclude group: 'com.android.volley', module: 'volley'
}
compile 'com.android.volley:volley:1.0.0'

comments.author: TWiStErRob
sjudd
comments.text:
You can't hold on to Targets weekly without breaking pretty much every Target that is not a ViewTarget (SimpleTarget, notification targets etc).
As is this will also cause NPEs for custom ViewTargets, so it's probably not something we can accept.
Typically when Targets are leaked, it's only for the duration of the load, which will eventually finish, often relatively quickly. Did you find a case where Targets are leaked permanently?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Hmm, I thought Glide.with(appContext).load(blah).into(imageView) leaks permanently... but I just read that ApplicationLifecycle doesn't hold on to the Targets the same way ActivityFragmentLifecycle does. (Rayco, Target is a LifecycleListener)

comments.author: raycoarana
comments.text:
Mmmm, sorry guys maybe is a false positive of LeakCanary. What we have is this leak:

GC ROOT com.bumptech.glide.load.engine.executor.FifoPriorityThreadPoolExecutor$DefaultThreadFactory$1. (anonymous subclass of java.lang.Thread)
references com.bumptech.glide.load.engine.executor.FifoPriorityThreadPoolExecutor$LoadTask.sync
references java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.callable
references java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.task
references com.bumptech.glide.load.engine.EngineRunnable.manager
references com.bumptech.glide.load.engine.EngineJob.cbs
references java.util.ArrayList.array
references array java.lang.Object[].[0]
references com.bumptech.glide.request.GenericRequest.target
references com.tuenti.glide.GlideMapper$5.view (anonymous subclass of com.bumptech.glide.request.target.BitmapImageViewTarget)
references com.tuenti.view.PhotoZoomView.mContext
leaks com.tuenti.PhotoActivity instance

I'm thinking that maybe this is true specially in cases where users have a very slow internet connection and try to load many images, that could leak activities for some time, even crashing the app because of OOM exception.
I will close this PR and further investigate it.
Thanks!

comments.author: TWiStErRob
sjudd
comments.text:
That's an interesting idea, I like it! I'll try that after I fix the main issue here:
It turns out this doesn't work directly as written because the annotation processor only runs on annotated files that are being compiled from source, not those included in aars. So the way this works right now, if you write a GlideModule in your application, the processor will pick it up, but if you depend on an integration library with a GlideModule, the processor will ignore it.
I can get around this by generating intermediate classes that are in a particular package and then adding an additional otherwise unused annotated class that's only included in applications, not libraries. The annotation processor will pick up the new annotated class and then in the processor, we can retrieve all the intermediate classes in our special package and generate the final module.
It's a little awkward, annotation processors don't really like combining classes.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Ok I think this is pretty much ready for review. This change does the following:

Adds ChildGlideModule and RootGlideModule abstract classes (Android convention to make it easier to change the interface later).
Adds @GlideModule annotation to find all Child and Root GlideModule implementations.
Adds @excludes annotation to allow RootGlideModule implementations to exclude any ChildGlideModule or any legacy GlideModule.

Going forward RootGlideModule will be the place to specify all application specific options. Only RootGlideModules will have the ability to change cache sizes/implementations and perform other configurations that affect Applications the most. There can be only one RootGlideModule per application.
ChildGlideModules only allow registering additional components (ModelLoaders, decoders etc). They're meant for libraries. There can be many ChildGlideModules per library or application.
This change will work side by side with the existing manifest registered GlideModule interface. Applications that don't include a RootGlideModule will see a log warning them to do so. All of the existing libraries that Glide provides offer both an annotation and a manifest version of their modules. When Applications have fully migrated to the annotation processor, they can disable manifest parsing in their RootGlideModule. If Applications want to migrate slowly, they can switch one module at a time and use the @excludes annotation to remove legacy GlideModule implementations as they go.
This change will require one additional gradle/maven dependency for each application and library for the annotation processor.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Didn't look deeply yet, but based on your comments: forcing apps to have RootGlideModule sounds strange. What if I'm happy with the defaults, do I need to include a module then?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
They're not going to be forced to have a RootGlideModule, but we will have a warning log because if you don't have a RootGlideModule and you want to include a library that has a ChildGlideModule, the ChildGlideModule will be ignored.
We can try to word the warning so that it doesn't seem scary if you're happy with defaults.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Some documentation for the requirements is here: http://sjudd.github.io/glide/doc/configuration.html.
It's a bit more work for users who want to use the annotation processor than it was for GlideModules, but it's backwards compatible and not strictly required if users don't have modules. It can be substantially faster than parsing the manifest for metadata. It also allows configuring Glide even on devices where there are weird errors trying to read metadata from manifests (one way this happens is when the amount of metadata in an Application's manifest exceeds the platform's memory limit).

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Yeah the tests here need to be cleaned up (see my earlier comment).
GlideApp is part of the generated API. The generated API is currently available only for Applications (it's only generated when we find a RootGlideModule).  I can't just use com.bumptech.glide.Glide for the generated API because it would break all non-application projects. Even if the generated API were available for libraries, you'd have a name collision if both the library and the application generated the same class in the same package (ie com.bumptech.glide.Glide).
The current thought on the generated API is:

Applications use the generated API by including a RootGlideModule and the name is different for the generated API to avoid confusion (defaults to GlideApp, but applications can change the name. For example the Google Photos version is called PhotosGlide).
Libraries (and Applications that don't want to deal with the complexity) use the existing Glide class and the fixed API.

Other solutions include:

Generating a Glide class for every library and/or application but base the Glide class on the package name (so you'd have com.google.android.apps.photos.Glide, com.bumptech.glide.integration.okhttp3.Glide etc).
Generate com.bumptech.glide.Glide for applications and force libraries to use a renamed GenericGlide/BaseGlide etc.
Generate com.bumptech.glide.Glide for applications and generate some other named class for libraries.

The two basic limitations are:

We need an annotated class to generate an API and especially to generate an API in a custom package (ie in the library or application's package). Right now, the best I can think of is to generate APIs for applications/libraries with Root or Child GlideModules.
We need a coherent way for libraries and applications to migrate. We could take a hard line approach, force everyone to use at least one GlideModule (Root or Child) and only expose Glide and similar APIs via generated code. However, doing so would break a bunch of snapshot users (and Google apps), so we'd probably need to fork and abandon the current master as a branch to accomplish this.

Thoughts definitely welcome. The main reason I put this up so early was to hopefully get comments on the generated API and how it can work with libraries, especially those that extend the API.

reviews.author: TWiStErRob
reviews.text: I personally prefer guards (return, continue) over nesting, it gives you a chance to have multiple conditions without having complex if condition expressions.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Wow, actually it's more than my personal preference, it's a PMD error, the build failure is because of this: https://pmd.github.io/pmd-5.4.0/pmd-java/rules/java/design.html#AvoidDeeplyNestedIfStmts
I suggest we close and abandon this change.

reviews.author: TWiStErRob
reviews.text:
I don't think that's SVG, there's no SVG in Android as far as I know, only vector drawables:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/drawable/VectorDrawable.html
The path descriptor mini-language is the only thing that's borrowed from SVG.
Please change the commit message to not mislead people.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Are you sure it breaks?

Does ProGuard handle Class.forName calls?
Yes. ProGuard automatically handles constructs like Class.forName("SomeClass") and SomeClass.class. The referenced classes are preserved in the shrinking phase, and the string arguments are properly replaced in the obfuscation phase. -- https://www.guardsquare.com/en/proguard/faq

comments.author: saschpe
comments.text: Yes. This was the important part. I'm using the beta version of the upcoming Android Gradle plugin. Not sure which Proguard version it uses internally.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
That section of the readme mentions that it's using the generated API and points to the documentation page that explains what the generated API is and how to use it.
You could argue that it's better to avoid the generated API in the readme for simplicity, but if you want to do that you'd need to update the entire readme to not use the generated API, including the link and the code immediately below this.
I'm inclined to push the generated API in the long run because it's much nicer to use.

comments.author: FrancoisBlavoet
comments.text:
Unrelated : should glide use @workerthread @mainthread annotations ?
That would make its API simpler to grok

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Yes, I support threading annotations, it helps a lot to know if you can do I/O and other stuff safely. All the components of the flow should be annotated. e.g. I never know if Transcoder is on UI or not. Annotations are more prevalent than the *

This will always be called on comments. Adding UI thread annotation on the listener/target interface will break a lot of people's builds (lint), in a good way!

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I'm willing to merge this. It's something that might go away in the future if it becomes burdensome, but I can't think of anything that would conflict with this behavior right now at least.
We should probably also try to follow up on the flashing when you manually clear() and restart requests separately. Maybe there's something else we can do to mitigate that case as well.

comments.author: Tolriq
comments.text:
Comment added.
To be honest fixing the flashing with clear would be cool as certainly can fix other things, but having devs to always call clear when their model have private fields that can't be exposed due to hashCode() seems way more hackish than this :(
Maybe another way would be to have an optional interface on the model to test for equity and call it if the model have it instead of equals for the request restart.
Kinda the same reasoning for your usage of isEquivalentTo and not equals. And have your isEquivalentTo call that one when available.
Edit: Actually last proposal sounds good, but will require the flashing fix to have everything working as currently :( As even successful requests would be restarted on completed if internal state changes.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Great thanks!
Can you file an issue with some details on your views that might help me track down why the flashing is occurring for your use case when you do clear? Is it in a RecyclerView? If so, are the views dimensions variable?
An optional interface is definitely worth more thought. Let's try to at least understand the flashing a bit better and go from there.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Thanks for putting this up, I really appreciate the detail and the repro case. This is definitely a complicated problem. I'm sorry for the delay, it took me a bit to wrap my head around this.
I think this solution isn't quite complete though. Let's say you have the same GIF animating in two views at the same time. Then, you stop both GifDrawables, one at a time, allowing exactly one additional frame to render before stopping the next GifDrawable.
When the first GifDrawable is stopped, after your change, it will end on frame N+1. Frame N will be cleared when frame N+1 loads.
When the second GifDrawable is stopped, one frame later, it will end on frame N+2. But, frame N+1, still in use by the first GifDrawable, will be cleared when frame N+2 loads.
We really should be assigning ownership of the frame to the stopped GifDrawable. The stopped GifDrawable should make a request to load the frame it currently has in view when stop() is called, which will ensure that the frame is not garbaged collected or re-used, even if the Target owned by the GifFrameLoader is cleared. When the stopped GifDrawable resumes or is destroyed, it can clear the Target it obtained in stop() and release the resource.
One way to do this might be to have stop() in the GifFrameLoader run the load and return a Target, then allow start() in GifFrameLoader to accept a @Nullable Target that could be cleared if the GifDrawable were resumed. I haven't tried that and you may also be able to come up with a better way to do even if that would work.

comments.author: Tolriq

Well equals/hashcode are OK for 99% of the time in other places as only the result matters.
Only issue would be 2 same target images with different path at the same time with the 1st one starting being a down path.
This leads to 2 failure instead of 1 fail / 1 success. Not a big deal for 99,99999% of use case I think.
And reading code, model is lost when reusing the job.
Implementing a fully working solution (Auto restart of second job if first one fails if model are not Equivalent) sounds overly complicated for this edge case. Let's keep things like that. And see if someone complains. The model equity already greatly improve controls for devs that needs it.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Do you have any context for why this is useful? Are there some devices where getExternalCacheDir always returns null? Are there any cases where the external cache directory is transiently null and then becomes valid later on?

comments.author: ANPez
comments.text:
For example, I have a Galaxy Nexus for testing purposes, where getExternalCacheDir returns null is there is no sd card present on the device.
It might aswell happen that SD card is temporarily unavailable, because of a temporary error, or by user interaction.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Would this make sense as a replacement for the existing external disk cache factory?
My only concern with transient failures is that you might end up swapping back and forth between two different cache directories each time the app is opened which would cause a  lot of additional cache misses and some unexpected storage usage.
Maybe we should always try the external one and if it ever goes away, permanently fall back to the internal directory? That way we'd at least avoid the churn problem? Or do you think transient failures are sufficiently unlikely that we shouldn't worry about them?

comments.author: ANPez
comments.text:
In my experience, in old Android 2.x days, those kind of transient errors where kinda usual. Nowadays, fortunately, things have changed as many phones come with enough space as users don't need cards.
But yes, that is a worry that you could end up with two copies of everything. In that case, I'd proceed as you suggested and, I'd got any error, always fall back to the internal one. I don't think it's worth it implementing some kind of a "merged cache provider" for internal and external files.
Finally, I've been using Glide for quite a long time and, when used external storage, I've always followed this pattern of trying external, and falling back to internal storage on error. Maybe there is a use case where you want to force external, but I can't think of any.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Ok, maybe deprecate the old external disk cache factory and add a comment suggesting using this one instead? 
  
    
      glide/library/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/load/engine/cache/ExternalCacheDiskCacheFactory.java
    
    
         Line 12
      in
      9018ae6
    
  
  
    

        
          
           public final class ExternalCacheDiskCacheFactory extends DiskLruCacheFactory { 
        
    
  

.
That way in a future version we can change the behavior while allowing some time to comment.
The only thing I can think of that would let you detect a previous failure would be to read/write a value to shared preferences that you'd check each time the disk cache was opened?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Might be a silly idea, but the existence of the internal cache folder could be the trigger for using the permanent fallback. If it once fell back to internal cache, then that folder was created, so subsequent times it's enough to check the existence of that, i.e.:
File internal = ...;
if (internal.exists()) return internal; // fallback was triggered in the past
FIle external = ...;
if (available(external)) return external; // preferred behavior
return internal; // fallback
(If someone wants to actually move from internal cache to preferred external cache, they would have to delete the internal cache folder anyway to clean up.)

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
You will still be able to triage, this is mostly going to target unlabeled issues or question labeled issues that no ones touched in a while. We can also re-open issues if the bot closes them.
Are you worried we have some older useful issues that aren't labeled?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
It's possible that some issues haven't been responded to, in the past year I haven't had much time, so there may be issues which are waiting for response from us. Those shouldn't be said to be stale.
Also unlabeled issues should be labeled as either questions or needs info and only then start the staling process. I can commit a day to do some triaging. Bot closing stuff and then we reopening is not ideal, because I assume that anything in a Closed has been processed by a human on the maintainer side at some point. If it starts closing issues I won't be able to have that distinction (i.e. don't know which issues need to be looked at).
Can you set a minimum issue number/date for the bot to start processing from? All I'm asking is to postpone this for a few days. (Sat, Sun, Mon), from Tue on I won't be available.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I can definitely wait until next week, there's no rush here. I'm trying to make sure I understand what your concerns are so that whatever solution we come up with addresses them.
My view is generally that if an issue is substantially old, regardless of who it's waiting on a response from, it's probably not worth keeping open. If the reporter hasn't followed up and no other users have commented or touched the issue, it's probably not hugely important. That said, I think most of the old issues are already labeled and won't be closed by this bot.
Mostly I'm aiming at all of the questions we get. I'd like to avoid closing them immediately when I answer them, but I don't have the patience to go back through and manually close them after N days if there's no follow up after we do provide an answer.
We do also have a pretty massive backlog that I don't want to go through manually either. The bot will comment on those and then give another 7 days for anyone in the issue to react before closing the issue, so hopefully it won't even get to close any issue someone wants to keep open, it will just prompt them to say something.

Edit:
There's a small issue left that can cause issues due to releasing of ressources a little too early.
Typically my animation use a listener for onAnimationEnd to reset the colorFilter and alpha. But in some cases it seems the animation is released from memory too early and the onAnimationEnd is not called. Leading the views in wrong states.
The simple fix is to clear those states in the cancel to cover all cases. But maybe this worth adding a note somewhere in the PR?

comments.text:
How would this function in Glide's internal build where traute is probably not available?



What do you mean by the Glide's internal build?

Glide is built by Bazel internally at Google.


Is there a performance overhead to checking for null? Typically I'd think the answer is no, but some methods may be called frequently enough or the number of null checks might be sufficient to introduce some overhead.



It doesn't add any overhead because it just replaces explicit calls to Preconditions.checkNotNull() to generated in-place checks.

It will if it adds an explicit null check everywhere the @NonNull annotation is used. Not all places that have @NonNull have explicit checks. Or at least it will add whatever overhead there is to checking non-null. In some cases it's likely these checks will be redundant because there will be a call on the non-null object in the method. The explicit preconditions checks are most useful in constructors or initialization methods where the object will be called in some other method later on.


How would this compare to nullability analysis (a build time check)?



This approach helps with built-time check because now target method parameters are marked by NotNull annotations, so, IDEs can highlight possible NPE - Android Studio documentation

@NonNull gives you this without the plugin. The plugin avoids explicit null checks in the code and/or provides some additional run time guarantees depending on how the @NonNull annotation is used right?
Nullability analysis theoretically provides you compile time checks so you can discover problems before you run the code in question. I'm not sure how robust or accurate these are. I think Uber has one: https://github.com/uber/NullAway.
One other thought - have you tested this to see what happens to line numbers in stack traces? Are they altered to account for the added null check so that line numbers are offset? Or are the original line numbers retained?

comments.author: denis-zhdanov
comments.text:
Hello,

I didn't find a way to apply javac plugins to Bazel builds. Asked on SO in case I missed something obvious. Just curious - why this project is configured to use Gradle instead of Bazel then?
not-null check is a single ifnonnull bytecode instruction. I didn't perform exact measurement, but it just doesn't have a chance to have any performance impact
Sure, line numbers are preserved. There are a number of tests for that like this one or this

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Gradle and the non-google build came first, but Gradle isn't used by most Android apps at Google (most use a variant of Bazel), so we needed a solution for that.
At some point in the future it may make sense to switch to Bazel for the external build. At the moment there's a lot of Gradle based infrastructure in Glide's build and Gradle is more clearly tied to Android externally, so I'm not sure it makes sense right now.
I'm also working on a change that will integrate Uber's nullability checker, it might make for an interesting test case. I don't think either precludes the other.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Why would the buffer be null if the stream is not closed? The buffer is set to a non-null value in the constructor and then set to null when the stream is closed. There are a few other methods that check if the buffer is null to see if the stream is closed.
For #2808 the two issues seem to be:

GIfDrawable requires a direct ByteBuffer
GifDrawable assumes that it can continue to read from the stream after the constructor completes

Glide definitely closes the stream after the decoder's decode method is finished, so 2 is expected.
Was there some other issue there that I missed?

comments.author: koral--
comments.text:
Why would the buffer be null if the stream is not closed? The buffer is set to a non-null value in the constructor and then set to null when the stream is closed.

null is assigned here in release():
https://github.com/bumptech/glide/blob/master/library/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/load/resource/bitmap/RecyclableBufferedInputStream.java#L118

GIfDrawable requires a direct ByteBuffer

It is one of the options but not the only one.

GifDrawable assumes that it can continue to read from the stream after the constructor completes

Indeed, input source is not buffered inside GifDrawable InputStream has to support marking.
In case of #2808 stream is not closed but only released.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Release and close are (or should be) called at more or less the same time, it's not going to be safe to continue to use the stream.

comments.author: koral--
comments.text: It does not happen in case of #2808, released stream is not closed.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Yes, but the stream it wraps is. If it's not closed, then it would be a significant memory leak. The expected flow is more or less:

ModelLoader returns a DataFetcher
DataFetcher returns an InputStream
DataRewinder wraps the InputStream with a recyleable stream
All relevant decoders are tried in order, with the stream rewound by the DataRewinder between each attempt
The DataRewinder releases its recycleable stream
The DataFetcher closes its stream

Glide doesn't allow decoders to retain references to unclosed streams as a rule. It's probably possible to get it to mostly work by avoiding the call to close in a custom ModelLoader/DataFetcher, but there aren't any guarantees.

comments.author: koral--
comments.text:
OK. Thanks for the explanation.
Is it intended that RecyclableBufferedInputStream#available() throws exception when stream is released but not closed?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Basically yes, released and closed are more or less equivalent. The only distinction is that release does not close the underlying stream, but close does.

comments.author: koral--
comments.text: So at least exception message is incorrect.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: It's mostly correct? For all practical purposes the stream is unusable. Does it make it more confusing to distinguish between the two states given that the end result is the same?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: I am still confused though, how does this solve #2808? What did you do to test it? The various read methods in the stream throw exactly the same exception for exactly the same reason. Why does changing the behavior of available() alone matter?

comments.author: koral--
comments.text: I've just checked out this project: https://github.com/Guang1234567/glide/tree/issue_503 and started analyzing what caused that issue (artifacts on the left image). Then I discovered that the stream cannot be read due to exception thrown from available() (read() calls available()). I saw that stream is not closed despite exception message saying it is closed. So I've modified available() to return 0 when stream is released and it turned out that it fixes #2808.

Here is the example, may be it is due to wrapping by BufferedInputStream: https://github.com/Guang1234567/glide/blob/issue_503/samples/svg/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/samples/svg/MyStreamGifDecoder.java#L62

comments.author: koral--
sjudd
comments.text:
Does GifDrawable read the stream it's given eagerly in a separate thread? If so it could just be a race condition I guess where available is called but the buffered stream already has the remainder of the image in memory so it never calls read again. Seems a little far fetched.
Fundamentally Glide doesn't provide support for progressive images, including GIFs. That feature could be added, but it's not currently supported. As long as GifDrawable is reading on a separate thread after the call to the constructor completes, the only safe way to implement this is to buffer the entire image in memory, which is best done via a ByteBuffer or byte[].  From that perspective this is basically broken as expected.
My curiosity is mostly about why it's broken in this particular way. I'd expect not all of the image data to be available so you'd at best see a partial GIF or a crash when you tried to read the remainder, at least once you change available(). It's not urgent enough for me to spend much time on since the high level issue (lack of support for progressive images) isn't supported.

comments.author: Anton111111
comments.text:
@sjudd , may be i do something wrong. But i try to show you how fix works.
I add small changes to Gallery sample to demonstrate problem.
I've add TextView to show log of preloading. You can see it on branch "demo_preload_problem" and try it himself (simple start gallery sample from my branch)
https://github.com/Anton111111/glide/blob/demo_preload_problem/samples/gallery/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/samples/gallery/MainActivity.java
I've removed my fix from ListPreloader.java and add log to onScroll method:
https://github.com/Anton111111/glide/blob/demo_preload_problem/library/src/main/java/com/bumptech/glide/ListPreloader.java
On start preload i write to log "Do preload from...".
I uploaded small video to youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rvkMHuh3-nE&feature=youtu.be
How you see "Do preload from" uppears in log only after user scroll. It happen because firstVisible and visibleCount variables equal 0 on first call onScroll (before user start scroll).
And i upload video with fix. You can see that preload start without user scroll.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0NKZe3w_1IQ
To check it himself simple init lastFirstVisible with -1 (how in my pull request)
And please ignore "OnScroll Preload firstVisible=x; lastFirstVisible=x" message in log ;)

comments.author: Unknown
comments.text: The correct loader was executed, but an error occurred, causing the next loader to be executed, but it should not be executed.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
The concerning cases in the referenced issue are the ones where the http loader was not executed.
If you just want to reduce some of the guaranteed to fail load attempts you can, but it doesn't fix the referenced issue.
If you do want the behavior you've added, then move the check for handles() into buildLoadData and return null if the wrapped loader returns false. That way we only  have to parse the Uri once.

Would you be willing to work on that instead of catching the exception here?
