comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Is it guaranteed that a split will always contain the parent package name? Or could they theoretically have any arbitrary package name?
It's definitely odd, but unless there's explicit framework support I'm not sure how you'd do better?

comments.author: SUPERCILEX
comments.text:
Yeah, that's the issue 😞. Since it's just a package defined in the manifest, I'm pretty sure you can have it be whatever you want (though the official examples do follow this pattern).
Sidenote: why are we throwing in the first place? Could we just return the original context if the new one isn't valid?

comments.author: SUPERCILEX
comments.text: @sjudd should we just not throw? It'll fail later on when it tries to load the resource anyway.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: What's the harm in throwing? Does it make a difference if the load's going to fail?

comments.author: SUPERCILEX
comments.text: Well the problem is that we throw too early since we don't know what the correct package for the resource is. I'm saying that if creating a new context fails, we just return the original context instead of throwing because loading the resource from that context may or may not fail.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: I'd rather keep the exception for now I think. It's probably better to clearly fail when the resource can't be found, even if we might have found it, than silently return the wrong image if the resource id happens to correspond with a different image in the containing package.

comments.author: SUPERCILEX
comments.text: Ohhh, I didn't think of that latter case, so SGTM for still throwing. 👍 Is this PR ready for purple then?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
This doesn't work. register() and unregister() are called in on onStart/onStop of every RequestManager, of which there's one per Fragment and Activity. With this change they'd all be sharing the same broadcast receiver and racing each other to register and unregister it.
Instead you'd need to consolidate the ConnectivityMonitor to a single instance and then do something like keep a count of all the starts and all the stops and only register when the count of started Activities/Fragments goes from 0->1 and only unregister when the count goes back to 0.

comments.author: bingranl
comments.text: Thanks for your PR, Sergey! I agree with you for changing the retention policy and make it aggregating. But I am wondering why are you adding originating element for those generated classes while you already make glide an aggregating annotation processor. As far as I know, aggregating AP doesn't need that and we are not able to know all the originating elements which is why we make it aggregating.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Thanks! I'm working on the build failure, it seems to be an issue with travis setup.
I'm also curious about the originating elements. Isolating annotation processor documentation mentions originating elements: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/java_plugin.html#example_an_isolated_annotation_processor. The aggregating documentation doesn't seem to. I've also found: gradle/gradle#4130

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Build error should be fixed if you rebase: b56dbab

comments.author: technoir42
comments.text:
I was not sure whether originating elements were required for aggregating AP so I added them anyway. Now, looking at the https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/7e2af8a93d4e8f21ff044cc971492717cc14ed7f/subprojects/language-java/src/main/java/org/gradle/api/internal/tasks/compile/processing/AggregatingProcessingStrategy.java#L67 I see that Gradle simply ignores them in case of an aggregating AP.
I've reverted everything related to originating elements and tested again, it seems that it works exactly the same. We can add them later if Gradle ever starts requiring them.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: I think we can't accept this without making sure that expired files are deleted relatively promptly. I'm not sure we'd make this the default disk cache even if that feature were implemented. Have you considered hosting this separately from Glide? We could certainly point to it as an option in documentation for users who want expiration and are ok with the edge cases here.

comments.author: dmytrodanylyk
comments.text:
I am ok to host that separately but would prefer to have it in Glide, since we use similar code in our application and it would be nice to have it in Glide.

deleted relatively promptly

Why do we need to do that? With the current implementation, if the expired file is accessed - it will be removed, if it's not accessed - it will be eventually removed by LRU mechanism or android system cleanup.
The important piece of functionality is not removing expired files, but making expired files not accessible.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Sorry for the delay. The internal migration at Google is progressing somewhat slower than hoped. My only other option is to use scripting to convert back and forth when code is imported/exported, which is non-trivial and I haven't yet had the chance to get to.
I also need to change the tool I use to run migrations to copybara (released publicly). Fortunately it appears as though someone has already written the migrations to/from androidx internally, so I may be able to kill two birds with one stone. That's my current plan.
I am curious as to how this is blocking anyone. I was under the impression that jetifier relieves most of these issues?

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text:
Have you tried reading the error messages?
https://travis-ci.org/github/bumptech/glide/jobs/617859292#L1572-L1653
Spotless tells you exactly what to change in a diff format, and I'm sure you can run gradlew checkstyle pmd to get the failures locally.

comments.author: kevinvanmierlo
comments.text:
I did look at it at the time, but didn't see the error messages in between. Thanks for the link to the specific lines. This was 2.5 years ago when I did this and did it besides my job, so must've looked over it.
Okay, would be great to use spotless, but it didn't work for me at the time. I didn't know about the checkstyle command, but I'll check it out next time.
I still do this besides my job, so I'll try to fix it as soon as I have time.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Sorry for the delay here. We actually have an internal version of a cronet integration that I'd be happy to open source. My main issue is that I haven't had the chance to figure out how to build cronet externally.
Where did you get the cronet files? Did you build them yourself?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Ok to answer my own question, there are a few versions of cronet available on maven: https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.chromium.net. However the recommended way to do depend on cronet is via gms core: https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/connectivity/cronet/start

comments.author: bgylde
comments.text:
Sorry for the delay here. We actually have an internal version of a cronet integration that I'd be happy to open source. My main issue is that I haven't had the chance to figure out how to build cronet externally.
Where did you get the cronet files? Did you build them yourself?

Yes, I compiled the cronet myself. Souce code was from chromium.

comments.author: bgylde
comments.text:
Ok to answer my own question, there are a few versions of cronet available on maven: https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.chromium.net. However the recommended way to do depend on cronet is via gms core: https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/connectivity/cronet/start

I had ever tried the play-services-cronet, but it has to depend on the google service. Or I can delete the cronet jar and so, just use the compileOnly way.

Thanks for the comment @sjudd. You are correct that this could not be enforced with ImageDecoder.  Do you have a suggestion on how to proceed with this?

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: I don't have any good ideas. If it can't be done with ImageDecoder, it's probably best not to expose the option for BitmapFactory. We're (slowly) moving towards ImageDecoder in Glide and it wouldn't surprise me if the framework continues to do the same.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: Sorry for the delay!

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
So my understanding is that the exception occurs when:

The gif starts playing
A frame is posted with a target delay
The gif is stopped, clearing the target but not removing the delay
Someone calls startFromFirstFrame
The delay finishes calling onFrameReady which sets the pendingTarget to be non-null
Eventually the gif is restarted and crashes because pendingTarget is non-null and startFromFirstFrame is true.

Does that  match your understanding?
If so, it seems like your fix will work, but only by effectively racily ignoring calls to startFromFirstFrame.
I might suggest an alternative fix, which is to avoid setting the pendingTarget if it completes while isRunning is false and startFromFirstFrame is true. It also seems to suggest there's a larger problem with the delay mechanism here where the delayed targets are not being cancelled. If we fixed that, you'd never get the call to onFrameReady and wouldn't have to make any changes.

comments.author: Tolriq
comments.text:
Beware of issues on Android 7 with callbacks being called without actual status yet being OK.
See for example google/ExoPlayer#7453 and I've faced that in my apps too.
I would recommend to only use the new approach on Android O(8.0)+

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Thanks for sending this, sorry for the delay.
I think this needs more work though. GIFs generally decode frame N+1 starting from the contents of frame N. There are a few different types of GIFs that use different disposal options, but certainly this is one of the more common types.
As a result, it's not safe to just decode the frames in reverse order. The starting points for the frames won't be correct.
I think the only way to implement this feature correctly is to cache all of the generated frames and just iterate backwards and forwards between them. I suppose you could also try to decode all frames up to N+1, then all frames up to N etc, but that would be quite slow. Of course simply caching the frames is also risky because a sufficiently large GIF probably can't be held entirely in memory. We could try to make sure the frames are cached on disk, but that also gets tricky because the decoder needs to decode frames in order, it doesn't support random access.
All of this to say, we'd need a significantly more complicated implementation.
I wonder if there's a gif library for java/android that supports this already? If so you might be able to write an integration library to use that one instead of Glide's default. See http://bumptech.github.io/glide/doc/configuration.html#registering-components and/or the examples in Glide's integration package: https://github.com/bumptech/glide/tree/master/integration

comments.author: ku8ar
comments.text:
@sjudd Thank you for your answer. As I understand it, it's not so trivial...
But suppose this algorithm meets my goals, because all the GIFs I use are saved in cache (and there are very small). So, in this case, am I able to write an extension or override StandardGifDecoder to somehow replace the logic of the advance() method?

reviews.author: kanelbulle
reviews.text:
The FIT_CENTER downsampler is documented as:
"Scales, maintaining the original aspect ratio, so that one of the image's dimensions is exactly equal to the requested size and the other dimension is less than or equal to the requested size."
(at the top of Downsampler.java)
Could you update this documentation to include the special case for 0-sized output?

reviews.author: kanelbulle
reviews.text:
Thanks for the change!
The checksum for the gradle-wrapper.jar does not match any known checksums of gradle releases. I think you might have built the wrapper without using the upgraded gradle version. See https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/gradle_wrapper.html#troubleshooting_a_checksum_mismatch for more info on how to correct this.

comments.author: EwoutH
comments.text:
Are you sure? The Gradle Wrapper Validation action reports:
Found known Gradle Wrapper JAR files:
3dc39ad650d40f6c029bd8ff605c6d95865d657dbfdeacdb079db0ddfffedf9f gradle/wrapper/gradle-wrapper.jar

comments.author: kanelbulle
comments.text: You're right, I didn't see that! I was comparing manually with the published SHAs. Sorry about that & thanks for the change!

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Thanks for sending this, but unfortunately there's some fundamental issues that wouldn't let us merge. Briefly:

We can't use reflection
The large amount of expensive decodes add in onResourceReady will be run on the main thread, which will introduce substantial amounts of jank.
The encoding isn't necessary to start the gif from a specific frame. You do need to decode each frame, but you don't then need to generate a new gif.

To make further progress, I'd instead suggest:

Expose an option in ByteBufferGifDecoder to set the start frame
In ByteBufferGifDecoder#decode, check the start frame, if it's not 0, then advance the decoder there the necessary number of times, being sure to decode each frame as you go (necessary for gifs that use certain disposal methods).

That's not the complete set of changes required for ByteBufferGifDecoder probably, you'd have to try it and see.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
I'd rather not comment out code as a general practice.
That said, I think the issue here is fundamentally that the framework is claiming it's going to use ARGB_8888 when we ask it, even if we say we want RGB_565. We might choose to ignore outConfig entirely, but I'm not sure that's the best idea. After all there may be cases where the framework can actually only produce ARGB_8888.
I think there's two things to do:

File a framework bug if we use inPreferredConfig = RGB_565,  inJustDecodeBounds=true, outConfig gives us ARGB_8888, but if we provide an input Bitmap with RGB_565 the decode just works fine. Preferably we'd have a test case for this
Up until whenever the framework bug in #1 is fixed, in Glide, try to decode with RGB_565 even if outConfig gives us ARGB_8888, but being sure to retry with ARGB_8888 if our RGB_565 load fails.

The best place to start is probably tests, rather than code. There's a bunch here, maybe we could add a new one or two? https://github.com/bumptech/glide/tree/master/instrumentation

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text:
Assuming this pattern is ok: #5237, I might be able to extract the animation portion into another modifier node.

Ok so I decided not to do this. Transitions are pretty concerned not just with the state of the request, but the presence / behavior of the placeholder, so I think they're a bit of a special case. We could still use this listener to compose a modifier that animates the layout, or even the combined placeholder + thumbnail(s) + main request during draw. But it's not very practical to use to animate between a placeholder and the finished request.
I suppose another option would be to extract the request, drawing the placeholder, and drawing the full image to separate nodes, but that's getting a bit complicated.

comments.author: sjudd
comments.text: It could be done with a default off log tag that's checked once statically? You could avoid capturing the stack trace unless it's enabled.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: I think a Log tag is not enough, they need to deploy it to production so that they can get crash traces from real devices. And they can't execute adb shell setprop there. It's not reproducible in dev envs as I understood. Glide users need to control this explicitly to opt in.

comments.author: TWiStErRob
comments.text: Although a simple static boolean variable would work, I guess.

comments.author: falhassen
comments.text: I added emulator tests to DownsamplerEmulatorTest. Unfortunately, my emulated device doesn't seem to reproduce this framework issue, but at least they can guard against regressions. Certainly, the emulated device can reproduce the non-default exif orientation bug when I disable the fix.

comments.author: falhassen
comments.text:
I added emulator tests to DownsamplerEmulatorTest. Unfortunately, my emulated device doesn't seem to reproduce this framework issue, but at least they can guard against regressions. Certainly, the emulated device can reproduce the non-default exif orientation bug when I disable the fix.

Actually, I found a bug in my commit where I configured the gainmap to use ARGB_8888. To reproduce the bug, I need to configure the gainmap to use ALPHA_8. Once I do that, the emulator test will fail without the workaround.

comments.author: falhassen
comments.text: Sorry, I think there is a bug in my last push. Will update once I fix...

comments.author: falhassen
comments.text: I fixed the issue. The bitmap.copy operation was setting all alpha values to zero. I copied the gainmap with a filter forcing the 100% opacity (which should be working-as-intended, since ALPHA_8 images only have a single channel).
